Award.AwardTitle: Promoting active learning in large undergraduate STEM courses: Identifying critical knowledge used by effective instructors

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Although active-learning teaching strategies can increase students' ability to learn fundamental concepts and develop scientific and critical thinking skills, the results that instructors achieve vary substantially. In order to support instructors to successfully implement active learning in undergraduate STEM, and thereby improve student outcomes, it is imperative to determine the instructor knowledge that facilitates effective active-learning instruction. Knowledge regarding teaching and learning, not just knowledge of course content, likely influences how instructors use active learning. The objective of this project is to elucidate and characterize critical differences in knowledge of experienced and highly effective (i.e., expert) active-learning instructors versus novice active-learning instructors in large (100+ students) undergraduate biology courses. To accomplish the project objective, a video-based instrument featuring clips from active-learning classrooms is being developed and validated. This instrument will measure instructors' knowledge of teaching and learning during active-learning lessons in large undergraduate courses. The developed instrument will make it possible to determine how expert and novice active-learning instructors differ in their knowledge.

Completion of this project will contribute in-depth understanding of the knowledge that is crucial to effective implementation of active learning. This project is also creating and making freely available high-quality videos of undergraduate instructors implementing active learning in large courses. These videos will provide a variety of examples of active learning, helping instructors to imagine how they might change their own instruction. This study will have a significant positive impact on our ability to facilitate faculty learning, and ultimately to improve student learning in undergraduate STEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Undergraduate instructors in the life sciences are being asked to replace lectures with active-learning instruction. Active-learning instruction engages students in challenging, collaborative problem solving during class, and is more effective than lecturing alone. Active-learning instruction results in students learning more and developing better scientific-thinking skills than lecture alone. It also helps to reduce achievement gaps between majority students and students from groups historically underrepresented in science. However, many college instructors struggle to effectively implement active-learning instruction. In order to support instructors to successfully implement active learning in undergraduate life sciences courses, and thereby improve student outcomes, it is imperative to determine the instructor knowledge that facilitates effective active-learning instruction.

 

The goal of this project was to better understand the teaching knowledge that is important to active-learning instruction, especially in large (50+ students) undergraduate life sciences courses. Specifically, we aimed to (1) develop and optimize a video-based survey to elicit teaching knowledge about active-learning instruction and (2) systematically compare the knowledge used by highly effective (i.e., expert) active-learning instructors versus novice active-learning instructors to determine what teaching knowledge is associated with effectiveness. We collected data from ~100 undergraduate life sciences instructors who use active-learning instruction in large courses to refine our video-based survey and make expert-novice comparisons. Furthermore, we aimed to create resources that helped instructors see what active-learning instruction could look like in the classroom. This project has resulted in the following discoveries and resources:

 

-We developed and carefully refined a video-based survey to elicit teaching knowledge. This research-based tool is modeled after instruments used with K12 teachers. It asks instructors to watch videos of real lessons that show both the instructor and the students. Instructors provide written answers to questions about what was effective in the lesson and what could be improved, as well as their reasoning for these evaluations. They also suggest improvements. The written analyses they provide of these lessons reveal the teaching knowledge they use to consider active-learning lessons. This survey is being used by other research teams to assess the impact of teaching professional development on teaching knowledge.

 

-One important type of teaching knowledge is pedagogical knowledge, which is knowledge about teaching and learning that is relevant across the various topics that instructors teach. Prior work has not defined the pedagogical knowledge that is important to active-learning instruction. In fact, pedagogical knowledge has been under-theorized across educational level and context. We drew on the thinking of 77 instructors to build a framework of the types of pedagogical knowledge employed by active-learning instructors and the connections among these types of knowledge.

 

-We discovered that expert (i.e., highly effective) active-learning instructors differ in important ways from novice active-learning instructors in the way that they analyze lessons. Experts rely on key types of knowledge more often than do novices. Specifically, experts are more likely to pay attention to whether students are being asked to do challenging cognitive work during class, whether students are being held accountable for completing that work, and whether the instructor is carefully monitoring and responding to student thinking during class. These are all examples of pedagogical knowledge. Experts are also more likely to display knowledge of teaching and learning specific topics, which is called pedagogical content knowledge.

 

-In addition to relying on different knowledge than novices, experts exhibited deeper teaching knowledge than novices. They were better able to support their evaluations of lessons and suggestions for improving lessons with clear reasoning.

 

-Our project also created seven videos of active-learning instruction in large undergraduate life sciences courses as resources for instructors. These videos are distinct from prior resources because they provide an in-depth and uninterrupted look at what happens in a classroom, including student-instructor interactions. These videos provide a variety of examples of active learning, helping instructors to imagine how they might change their own instruction. These videos also show a range in the quality of active-learning instruction, which makes them useful resources for teaching professional development. Teaching training programs around the country use these videos as discussion starters and for in-depth lesson analysis to build participant?s teaching knowledge. We organized these videos with other curated videos to support active-learning instruction in a video repository called REALISE: Repository for Envisioning Active-Learning Instruction in Science Education (https://seercenter.uga.edu/realisevideos/).

 

To date, there have been few studies of teaching knowledge among undergraduate STEM instructors. Our research has produced new insights into the knowledge that by active-learning instructors possess and teaching knowledge that may be especially important to effective implementation of active-learning instruction in large classes. This contribution to our can inform efforts to train and support instructors to adopt and effectively implement active-learning instruction. Our work has also contributed a new theoretical framework that can be used by other researchers, as well as a new tool for studying teaching knowledge in undergraduate life sciences instructors.
